        6. Questions put to Mario Marsh, a former detective, to prove that he was removed from the police force earlier this year because he had lost the confidence of the Commissioner.” 
        
       
      
    193 In R v Lumsden [2003] NSWCCA 83 the CCA divided over whether evidence of a prior conviction of a defence witness had substantial probative value. Smart AJ held that it did not; Hulme J, with whom Mason P agreed, held that it did. 
     
      
    194 The critical Crown witness was Simpson. He was the witness subjected to the lengthiest and most sustained attack in cross-examination. Cross-examination on issues of credit alone extended over at least 194 pages of transcript. It covered a diverse range of topics, from allegations of rape of the appellant’s eighteen month old stepdaughter, sexual molestation of the appellant’s son, and the use of firearms, to making false representations to a real estate agency in connection with an application for the lease of residential premises. Besides those matters, Simpson was cross-examined about: 
     
      
    - his honesty generally;- specific instances of lying to various courts and tribunals;- bribery of police officers;- indemnity against prosecution for a variety of offences;- instances of perverting or attempting to pervert or conspiring to pervert the course of justice;- conspiracy to commit tax offences;- tax evasion;- assaults on various women with whom the appellant had had a relationship;- the sentencing discount as a result of the appellant’s cooperation with authorities;- engaging in drug business with “bikies’ gangs”;- the extent of the appellant’s past drug manufacturing;- the appellant’s criminal record;- the appellant’s participation in a witness protection programme;- alleged bigamy;- a custody application in relation to the appellant’s son (with suggested perjury);- procuring Proctor to make a false affidavit;- drug use;- threats to a former de facto;- domestic violence;- association with an armed robber;- avoiding service of court process;- apprehended violence orders in relation to one of the appellant’s wives and children;- deceiving officers of the Probation and Parole Service with respect to marital status, accommodation, employment;- supplying drugs to young people at rock concerts. 
     
      
    195 The cross-examination of Proctor commenced with a suggestion that he was a “career fraudster” and proceeded to his criminal history (which was extensive). 
     
      
    196 It would be altogether too time consuming to attempt to refer to all of the matters raised in cross-examination of other Crown witnesses. It is obvious from the outline given above, and that given by Armitage DCJ, that the areas of cross-examination ranged from the serious to the relatively trivial. 
     
      
    197 The question is whether the conduct of the cross-examination of the prosecution witnesses, alone or in conjunction with other circumstances, warranted a grant of leave under s104(2). 
     
      
    198 In this context reference should also be made to s112 of the Evidence Act which is in the following terms: 
     
      
       
        
        “A defendant is not to be cross-examined about matters arising out of evidence of a kind referred to in this Part unless the court gives leave.” 
        
       
      
    199 The “Part” is Part 3.8 of the Evidence Act, concerned with character. A question arises as to the meaning of “matters arising out of evidence of a kind referred to in this Part”; in Stanoevski v The Queen [2001] HCA 4; 202 CLR 115, the High Court declined to attempt to “harmonise” Part 3.8 with Part 3.7 (concerned with credibility, in which s104 appears). S110, also in Part 3.8, is concerned with evidence adduced on behalf of a defendant intended to establish good character, either generally or in a particular respect. One construction, probably the most obvious construction, of s112 is that it only prohibits cross-examination of a defendant about matters arising out of evidence called on his or her behalf to establish good character. Thus the discretion to grant leave to cross-examine a defendant about character does not exist and is not triggered, unless and until a defendant gives or adduces evidence of good character, either generally or in a particular respect. The alternative construction is that “evidence of a kind referred to in this Part” is character evidence, in which case leave could be given (subject to s192 considerations and ss135 and 137) whether or not the defendant has raised good character. If the latter is the correct construction, then s112 prohibits cross-examination on character whether or not the defendant has raised character, subject to leave being granted. If the former is the correct construction, then there is nothing (other than s102) that expressly prohibits cross-examination of an accused person in relation to previous criminal history. However, even on this construction, s112 is relevant, in my view, to show that the common law resistance to allowing evidence of prior criminal history is still relevant in guiding the exercise of the s104(2) discretion: see R v Ellis [2003] NSWCCA 319; 58 NSWLR 700; 144 A Crim R 1: Kevin William Phillips v The Queen [1985] HCA 79; 159 CLR 45. 
     
      
    200 After considerable hesitation I have come to the view that it was open to his Honour to exercise his discretion (in which I include performing the relevant balancing exercises) in the manner in which he did. In my opinion, the exercise involved a fine balancing of competing considerations. The evidence of the prior conviction was, in my opinion, likely to have been highly prejudicial to the appellant. (That prejudice was somewhat diminished by reason of the very different nature of the corruption offence from the offences with which the appellant was charged. It could not, therefore, have led the jury mistakenly to treat it as tendency evidence.) The evidence was also highly probative in relation to his credibility. In the ordinary course, it would seem to me that the danger of unfair prejudice created by evidence of a serious criminal conviction would substantially outweigh its probative value. However, that assessment has to be made in the light of the fairness considerations. I emphasise that it would not be every case where an attack is made upon the credibility of the Crown witnesses that would warrant the exercise of the 104(2) discretion to grant leave to cross-examine in relation to such a serious matter. Caution would have to be exercised in assessing overall fairness, and in the balancing exercises. Legal representatives of persons charged with serious criminal offences must have substantial flexibility in their approach to cross-examining prosecution witnesses, without fear that attacks on those witnesses, if made within proper limits, will expose their clients to the potential disclosure of their criminal histories, or alternatively, operate as a disincentive to their exercising the option to give evidence.  
     
      
    201 In this case a different judicial mind may have reached a different result. But this Court will not substitute its own discretion for that of the trial judge unless error in the exercise has been shown. Having regard to the nature of the attack, made particularly upon Simpson, but also upon each of the other indemnified witnesses, it seems to me that it was open to his Honour to come to the view that he did.  
     
      
    202 For these reasons I agree that ground 5 should be rejected. 
     
      
       
      ground 8 
       
      
    203 As pleaded, ground 8 attacked the directions given in relation to the credibility of Simpson and a failure to put the defence case. In the written submissions filed on 21 June 2004 this ground was said to be not pressed and incorporated into ground 7. 
     
      
       
      ground 10: “unreasonable verdicts” 
       
      
    204 Before proceeding to a consideration of the matters raised in support of this ground, it is as well to repeat, yet again, the much quoted passage from M v The Queen [1994] HCA 63; 181 CLR 487 at [493]: 
     
      
       
        
        “Where, notwithstanding that as a matter of law there is evidence to sustain a verdict, a court of criminal appeal is asked to conclude that the verdict is unsafe and unsatisfactory, the question which the court must ask itself is whether it thinks that upon the whole of the evidence it was open to the jury to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the accused was guilty. But in answering that question the court must not disregard or discount either the consideration that the jury is the body entrusted with the primary responsibility of determining guilt or innocence, or the consideration that the jury has had the benefit of having seen and heard those witnesses. On the contrary, the court must give full regard to those considerations.” (internal references omitted) 
        
       
      
    205 The attack upon the sustainability of the two verdicts of guilty was based upon the asserted unreliability as a witness of Simpson. Considerable weight was placed upon his acquittal on count 1, it being suggested that this should be read as a rejection by the jury of his credibility; it then being argued that that rejection should have translated to his reliability in his evidence on the two other counts. 
     
      
    206 The argument was put that Simpson’s evidence as to the Dooralong premises was uncorroborated but that this was not properly drawn to the attention of the jury. There was other evidence that the appellant had been present at the Dooralong house, including evidence that the appellant, with Simpson, was setting up the manufacturing process; but this evidence was given by witnesses who themselves had been involved and were therefore accomplices. It could not, therefore, it was argued, properly amount to corroboration. Indeed, a great deal was made of the question of corroboration. 
     
      
    207 Armitage DCJ gave these directions: 
     
      
       
        
        “I warn you specifically that the evidence of the person himself or herself involved in a criminal enterprise cannot be relied upon by the Crown to strengthen the evidence of another person himself or herself involved in that same enterprise. By way of one example only, the fact that Richard Simpson has given evidence that the accused was at the premises at Dee Why cannot be used to strengthen Georgina Phillip’s evidence that the accused was at Dee Why. ... I warn you that, where the evidence of a person or persons involved in the same crime or crimes as that alleged against the accused is relied upon by the Crown, it is dangerous to convict in the absence of strengthening evidence which confirms or tends to confirm the involvement of the accused. As I have said, the Crown submits that such evidence is before you in relation to the Sylvania Waters matter.” 
        
       
      
    208 In my opinion, the reference to the absence of corroboration, and the inability of accomplices to corroborate one another, is apt to mislead. By s164 of the Evidence Act common law rules that required corroboration in respect of certain offences (excepting perjury or similar or related offences) are abolished. The common law rule that an accomplice could not corroborate the evidence of another accomplice was directed to those cases in which corroboration was required. If, in relation to a charge in respect of which corroboration was required, the only evidence available to support the evidence of one participant in the crime was that of another participant, then, as a matter of law, the evidence would not sustain the charge. Notwithstanding the provisions of s164(3), this Court has held that:  
     
      
       
        
        “ ... the power and duty to [give an accomplice warning] in appropriate circumstances survives: see also s165(5): [ 
        R v Chen & Ors 
         [2002] NSWCCA 174; 130 A Crim R 300 at [57]].” 
        
       
      
    209 In a case in which a principal Crown witness was an accomplice the Court held: 
     
      
       
        
        “It became, therefore, incumbent upon the learned presiding judge to give the jury clear direction to the effect that it would be dangerous to convict the appellant, and his other co-accused, upon the uncorroborated evidence of that accomplice.” 
        
       
      
    210 In this case Armitage DCJ gave precisely the kind of direction that Chen mandates is still required. 
     
      
    211 It was not strictly necessary that Simpson’s evidence be corroborated. The evidence of the indemnified accomplices was evidence that supported his evidence in some respects. Their evidence was, of course, suspect, but this was adequately drawn to the jury’s attention, and there was no reason why the jury could not, if it saw fit, act upon that evidence. I do not accept that Simpson’s evidence in respect of the Dooralong count was uncorroborated, or that, even if it were, that is anything more than one consideration in relation to the sufficiency of the evidence in the Crown case. The direction given was unduly favourable to the appellant. There was no reason why the evidence of the indemnified witnesses should not have been used to support Simpson’s evidence, provided proper warnings were given (as was done) about the reliability of the witnesses. 
     
      
    212 The next point made in relation to the unreasonable verdict ground concerned the asserted “total unreliability” of Simpson. A number of factors were pointed to as affecting his reliability. These were put in this way: 
     
      
       
        
        “ ... He was an admitted serial perjurer, bigamist, lifetime criminal, and career illegal chemist with a tendency to lie.” 
        
       
      
    213 Also relied upon was an issue which had arisen concerning allegations that had been made against him many years in the past concerning sexual abuse of a stepdaughter. 
     
      
    214 Reliance was placed upon the decision of this Court in R v Ralph and George (1988) 37 A Crim R 202. There the Court allowed an appeal against conviction and entered verdicts of acquittal in a case in which essentially the entire Crown case was given through a witness who was an accomplice, a convicted criminal, involved in the importation and trafficking of narcotics, an admitted liar and one who was capable of clever deception. The majority of the Court said: 
     
      
       
        
        “The conclusion which we have reached is that, because the quality of the evidence of Smith must necessarily be unacceptable unless corroborated in material respects (which it was not), it was not open to the jury to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt as to the guilt of either of the accused.” 
        
       
      
    215 This is not a proposition of law, but a reason given by the Court as then constituted for finding a conviction, in the language then used, to be unsafe and unsatisfactory. 
     
      
    216 It cannot be used as a statement of general application. In the present case there were obvious questions relating to the credibility of Simpson and other witnesses. But these were all adequately dealt with and the jury was fully entitled, after giving due consideration to the evidence, to rely on the totality of the evidence to convict. 
     
      
    217 Another matter argued on behalf of the appellant was what was said to be “an inherent inconsistency and hence unreasonableness” in the verdict on count 2 in the light of the acquittal on count 1. The acquittal on count 1 was attributed to the jury’s apparent rejection of Simpson’s evidence. (It was conceded that count 3 was in a different position, presumably because the appellant was arrested at the location and the surveillance and telephone intercept evidence.) 
     
      
    218 I do not see any such “inherent inconsistency”. The first count alleged participation in the manufacture of a prohibited drug; the second and third counts alleged conspiracy to manufacture a prohibited drug. The first count thus depended on the Crown establishing beyond reasonable doubt that the drug was in fact manufactured. The second and third counts did not. Conspiracy was complete when the agreement was made and established when the agreement was proved beyond reasonable doubt. 
     
      
    219 As will be apparent from the reasons given in relation to ground 3, there was a real issue about whether, at Dooralong or Sylvania Waters, the drug methylamphetamine had been manufactured out of the materials available. That, in my opinion, does not affect the proof of a conspiracy, even though the conspiracy was doomed to failure, but a question about the adequacy of the materials to produce methylamphetamine certainly affected proof of the elements of the first count. 
     
      
    220 Only the evidence of Simpson established that methylamphetamine was produced at Dee Why. That in itself is sufficient to explain the different verdict on count 1. 
     
      
    221 Applying the test in M, I am satisfied that it was open to the jury, upon the whole of the evidence, to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the appellant was guilty. 
     
      
    222 I would reject this ground of appeal. 
     
      
    223 I agree with the orders proposed by Santow JA. 
     
      
       
      
    224 SPERLING J: I have had the advantage of reading in draft the judgments of Santow JA and Simpson J. 
     
      
    225 I agree with Santow JA that grounds 3(A) and 3(B) should be rejected and with Simpson J that grounds 1(A), 1(B), 1(C), 2(A), 2(B), 2(C) and 10 should be rejected. I also agree with Santow JA in relation to sentence. 
     
      
    226 For the purpose of dealing with grounds 5, 7 and 9, I gratefully adopt the introductory observations of Santow JA and the resume of the evidence provided by Simpson J. 
     
      
       
      Ground 5: His Honour erred in allowing the accused to be cross-examined by the Crown Prosecutor as to: 
       
       
      (a) A police departmental charge of disobedience relating to a failure to make an occurrence pad entry. 
       
       
      (b) A police departmental charge of disobedience or a direction authorising a trip to Bali. 
       
       
      (c) Alleged threats made by the accused to Richard Simpson and Katie Ingall. 
       
       
      (d) A criminal conviction under section 186 Crimes Act. 
       
      
    227 In two judgments given on 6 December 2002, Armitage DCJ ruled, over objection by counsel for the appellant, that the Crown Prosecutor should have leave to cross-examine the appellant in relation to the matters referred to in ground 5 in the event that the appellant gave evidence.  
     
      
    228 The relevant provisions of the Evidence Act 1995 are, so far as is material, as follows. 
     
      
       
        
        102 The credibility rule 
        
       
       
        
         
          
          Evidence that is relevant only to a witness’s credibility is not admissible. 
          
         
        
       
       
        
        103 Exception: cross-examination as to credibility 
        
       
       
        
        (1) The credibility rule does not apply to evidence adduced in cross-examination of a witness if the evidence has substantial probative value. 
        
       
       
        
        (2) Without limiting the matters to which the court may have regard in deciding whether the evidence has substantial probative value, it is to have regard to: 
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (a) whether the evidence tends to prove that the witness knowingly or recklessly made a false representation when the witness was under an obligation to tell the truth, and 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (b) the period that has elapsed since the acts or events to which the evidence relates were done or occurred. 
          
         
        
       
       
        
        104 Further protections: cross-examination of accused 
        
       
       
        
        (1) This section applies only in a criminal proceeding and so applies in addition to section 103. 
         
         
        (2) A defendant must not be cross-examined about a matter that is relevant only because it is relevant to the defendant’s credibility, unless the court gives leave. 
         
         
        (3) …. 
         
         
        (4) Leave must not be given for cross-examination by the prosecutor about any matter that is relevant only because it is relevant to the defendant’s credibility unless: 
         
         
          
          (a) evidence has been adduced by the defendant that tends to prove that the defendant is, either generally or in a particular respect, a person of good character, or 
          
         
         
          
          (b) evidence adduced by the defendant has been admitted that tends to prove that a witness called by the prosecutor has a tendency to be untruthful, and that is relevant solely or mainly to the witness’s credibility. 
          
         
         
        (5) A reference in subsection (4) (b) to evidence does not include a reference to evidence of conduct in relation to:  
         
          
           
            
           
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (a) the events in relation to which the defendant is being prosecuted, or 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (b) the investigation of the offence for which the defendant is being prosecuted. 
          
         
        
       
       
        
        (6) …. 
        
       
       
        
        135 General discretion to exclude evidence 
        
       
       
        
         
          
          The court may refuse to admit evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger that the evidence might: 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (a) be unfairly prejudicial to a party… 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (b) … 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (c) … 
          
         
        
       
       
        
        136 General discretion to limit use of evidence 
        
       
       
        
         
          
          The court may limit the use to be made of evidence if there is a danger that a particular use of the evidence might:  
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (a) be unfairly prejudicial to a party, or 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (b) be misleading or confusing. 
          
         
        
       
      
     
     
      
       
        
        137 Exclusion of prejudicial evidence in criminal proceedings 
         
         
          
          In a criminal proceeding, the court must refuse to admit evidence adduced by the prosecutor if its probative value is outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant. 
           
          
         
        
       
       
        
        192 Leave, permission or direction may be given on terms 
        
       
       
        
        (1) If, because of this Act, a court may give any leave, permission or direction, the leave, permission or direction may be given on such terms as the court thinks fit. 
        
       
       
        
        (2) Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in deciding whether to give the leave, permission or direction, it is to take into account: 
         
          
         
          
          (a) the extent to which to do so would be likely to add unduly to, or to shorten, the length of the hearing, and 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (b) the extent to which to do so would be unfair to a party or to a witness, and 
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (c) the importance of the evidence in relation to which the leave, permission or direction is sought, and  
          
         
        
       
       
        
         
          
          (d) the nature of the proceeding … 
          
         
        
       
      
    229 As at 6 December 2002, when his Honour made the relevant ruling, Crown witnesses had been extensively cross-examined. Many of those witnesses had received an indemnity against prosecution for extensive and serious criminal conduct, much of which was unrelated to the events in relation to which the appellant was being prosecuted. The cross-examination emphasised and, in some cases, brought out the criminal histories of these witnesses. It was important evidence tending to establish that the relevant witnesses had a motive to give evidence which would support the Crown’s case against the appellant. 
     
      
    230 In the first judgment of 6 December 2002, his Honour listed the instances of cross-examination of Crown witnesses relied on by the Crown Prosecutor in support of the application for leave to cross-examine the appellant. His Honour said: 
     
      
       
        
        In support of his application pursuant to s104(4)(b), the Crown Prosecutor relies upon cross-examination of various Crown witnesses eliciting evidence which, he submits, does not fall within s104(5). The cross-examination upon which he specifically relies is as follows: 
        
       
       
        
        (1) Questions put to Robert Proctor in an effort to establish that he was a “career fraudster”, and other questions put to him in relation to a conviction for carnal knowledge. 
        
       
       
        
        (2) Question put to Georgina Phillips, in response to which she conceded that she had forged documents for the purpose of obtaining a carer’s pension for her deceased mother. 
        
       
       
        
        (3) Questions put to Trent Brown in relation to convictions he has for offences including break, enter and steal, escaping from lawful custody, assault, stealing, and receiving. 
        
       
       
        
        (4) The tendering in evidence by the accused of the criminal records of Richard Simpson, Robert Proctor, Trent Brown and Georgina Phillips. 
        
       
       
        
        (5) Questions put to Georgina Phillips concerning a shoplifting offence. 
        
       
       
        
        (6) Questions put to Mario Marsh, a former detective, to prove that he was removed from the Police Force earlier this year because he had lost the confidence of the Commissioner. 
        
       
      
    231 In one other respect, it is necessary to record some of what had transpired in the trial prior to the ruling.  
     
      
    232 The Crown says there was an issue at the trial as to whether the police were “out to get” the appellant. In his opening statement to the jury which immediately followed the Crown’s opening address, counsel for the appellant is recorded as saying: 
     
      
       
        
        Why are the police so intent on prosecuting Mr El Azzi. You might think that he they want to silence him. As a Crown opened to you it was said that he was a cop. Knows too much, must be silenced. The police eat their own. 
        
       
       
      Counsel for the appellant was mistaken. Nothing of the kind had been said by the Crown Prosecutor in his opening address. Some such comment had been made in the opening address at a previously aborted trial. 
       
      
    233 The issue was in fact introduced by counsel for the appellant in the opening statement to which I have referred. It was then pursued by counsel in the cross-examination of Detective Willingham. The witness was asked by counsel whether he had a wish to silence the appellant by investigating and charging him. 
     
      
    234 I return to the judgments of 6 December 2002. The first judgment related to the two misconduct matters and the alleged threats. The second related to the criminal conviction. 
     
      
    235 In the first judgment, his Honour recorded submissions by counsel for the appellant (1) that the evidence sought to be led in cross-examination was not of substantial probative value as required by s103 of the Act, (2) that leave should not be given because it would be unfair if the relevant Crown witnesses could not be cross-examined for the purpose of revealing a motive to lie and (3) that, if the Crown was entitled to leave, the evidence should be rejected pursuant to s137 or s135. 
     
      
    236 As to the second of these submissions, the witnesses had, of course, already been cross-examined. The gist of the submission was that it would be unfair, in the circumstances of the case, to subject the appellant to the penalty of cross-examination as to credit on the ground that his counsel had undertaken a proper cross-examination of Crown witnesses as to credit. 
     
      
    237 His Honour was alert to the question of unfair prejudice arising from the evidence being allowed. He quoted the following passage from the decision of the High Court in Phillips (1985) 159 CLR 45, at 57-58. 
     
      
       
        
        It is right to stress the exceptional character of a case in which the credibility of an accused person is open to be attacked by reference to his bad character or previous convictions and it is undoubtedly right that the discretion of a trial judge to permit such an attack be sparingly and cautiously exercised. Although the purpose for which such evidence is admitted is confined to questions touching the credibility of an accused person and is not to be accepted by the jury as persuasive of his guilt of the offence charged and notwithstanding that the trial judge will direct the jury clearly as to the use to which the evidence may be put and the use to which it may not be put (cf.  
        Reg. v Beech 
         (1978) 20 SASR 410, at pp 420-423) there will always be a keen appreciation that the admission of the evidence may in the absence of countervailing considerations operate unfairly to his prejudice. The operation of the statute as construed in  
        Curwood  
        and confirmed in  
        Dawson 
         (1961) 106 CLR 1 will determine when the statutory discretion arises. When that occurs, the sole criterion governing its exercise is what fairness requires in the circumstances of the particular case. 
        
       
      
    238 His Honour went on to say: 
     
      
       
        
        I am satisfied that the leave sought should be granted. The attack on all the important Crown witnesses was substantial and sustained, and it strayed into areas remote from the matters in issue. I am satisfied that evidence adduced by the accused has been admitted that tends to prove that witnesses called by the prosecutor have a tendency to be untruthful, and that is relevant solely or mainly to the credibility of those witnesses. 
        
       
       
        
        I accept the Crown Prosecutor’s submission that in view of the defence contention that, in effect, the police were out to get the accused, it is appropriate that there be evidence before the jury of some incidents in the accused’s career. 
        
       
       
        
        As to the threats allegedly made by Mr Simpson and Miss Ingall, evidence of those matters is already before the jury. In my view, it is appropriate that the accused, if he gives evidence, be questioned by the Crown Prosecutor about those matters. 
        
       
       
        
        In coming to the view that leave should be granted in relation to certain areas of the proposed cross-examination, I have considered s192 of the Act. I do not consider that the proposed cross-examination would be likely to add unduly to the length of the hearing. It does not appear to me that the granting of leave is unfair to the accused. The evidence proposed is in my view important. I am fully cognizant of the nature of the proceedings, and I take that into account. 
        
       
      
    239 I do not read the first of the paragraphs quoted above as being critical of trial counsel for the appellant. In particular, I do not read the passage as a finding by his Honour that Crown witnesses had been cross-examined more extensively than was reasonably necessary or otherwise improperly. I read the reference to cross-examination straying into areas remote from the matters in issue as going to the inapplicability of subsection (5) of s104 and not as a finding of over-zealous cross-examination. 
     
      
    240 His Honour’s reasons for decision in the second judgment of 6 December 2002 (which related to the criminal conviction) were as follows: 
     
      
       
        
        Mr Waterstreet submits I should not allow the cross-examination. It is his submission that the probative value of the evidence is outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the accused. I reject that submission. In my view the matter is of substantial probative value which is not outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the accused. 
        
       
       
        
        If the offence in question had in any way been drug related, the situation may well have been different. In my view I am not required to reject the proposed cross-examination pursuant to s317. In my view I should not reject it in the exercise of my discretion pursuant to s135. 
        
       
       
        
        In reaching the view I have about the matter I take into account the matters referred to in s192 of the Evidence Act. In particular, the extent to which, if I give leave, the cross-examination will be likely to add unduly to, or shorten, the length of the hearing; as to 192(2)(b), in my view there is no unfairness to the accused involved in the decision that I have made. Sub-paragraph 2(c), in my view the evidence is important. Again, I have regard to the nature of these proceedings. I take all those matters into account. 
        
       
      
    241 In the judgment, as recorded, there is a full-stop after “sub-paragraph 2(c)” in the passage quoted above. I have substituted a comma to convey the sense of the passage.

For perjury, you might think, self interest definitely.

As you recall the accused was cross-examined by the Crown Prosecutor about a conviction that he has for a certain offence  
        [mistyped “defence”]  
        committed by him in 1994 for which he was sentenced to a period of community service. He was also questioned about two departmental charges, one in 1986, one in 1987. The first an offence of alleged disobedience relating to his failure to make a note in an occurrence pad. The second in relation to a holiday in Bali that he took without permission. It is very important that you understand that that cross-examination was directed at the accused’s credibility only. I emphasises that the evidence is not to be accepted by you as in any way persuasive of the accused’s guilt of any one of the three charges that you are now considering, or as evidence the accused was likely to commit these particular offences.
